In the Fourth Satire of the Second Book, Horace ridicules, in a vein of exquisite irony, the gourmets of his day, who made a philosophy of flavours, with whom sauces were a science, and who had condensed into aphorisms the merits of the poultry, game‚ or fish of the different and often distant regions from which they were brought to Rome. Catius has been listening to a dis- sertation by some Brillat-Savarin of this class, and is hurrying home to commit to his tablets the precepts by which he professes himself to have been immensely ΒἬ, when he is met by Horace, and prevailed upon to· eat some of them in the very words of this philoso- pher of the dinner-table.
